conclusion: Trying to solve a problem about particles going through a particle accelerator and a velocity selector.
First particle with mass m and charge q is accelerated by particle accelerator M from rest at point S to velocity v.
Particle goes through velocity selector N with uniform electric and magnetic fields perpendicular to each other, magnetic field into the page with flux density B.
Particle passes through N along a straight line parallel to conductive plates.
Second particle with mass 2m and charge q starts from rest at point S and goes through the same accelerator and selector, departing from N with deviation d from dashed line.
Need to find kinetic energy of second particle when it leaves N.
First particle is accelerated from rest to velocity v by accelerator M.
Electric and magnetic forces on first particle in velocity selector are balanced for straight-line motion: qE = qvB, thus E = vB.
Second particle with mass 2m and charge q also starts from rest and goes through accelerator M.
Problem doesn't specify if acceleration is same for both particles or depends on their masses.
If accelerator M applies constant potential difference U, energy gained by particle is qU, converted into kinetic energy.
For first particle: 1/2 m v^2 = qU, thus v = sqrt(2qU/m).
In velocity selector, E = vB for first particle.
For second particle: 1/2 (2m) v'^2 = qU, thus v' = sqrt(qU/m).
In velocity selector for second particle, electric and magnetic forces don't cancel because v' is different from v.
Electric force is qE downward, magnetic force is q v' B upward.
Since v' < v, magnetic force q v' B is less than qE, causing net downward force on second particle.
Net force causes particle to deviate from straight path by distance d.
To find kinetic energy of second particle when it leaves N, consider work done by electric field as it traverses selector.
Time particle spends in selector is t = L/v', where L is selector length.
Net force on particle is F_net = qE - q v' B.
